image.altText: Anthony Albanese during an interview on Insiders

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese vows he is an "honest person" as he continues to defend breaking an election commitment on the contentious stage 3 tax cuts.

title.children: Prime minister defends integrity as he explains tax cut change

image.altText: A hand holds an Aboriginal flag in front of a large banner

props.synopsis: WARNING: This story includes names and images of Aboriginal people who have died. Dr Lowitja O’Donoghue, who fought endlessly for the rights of her people, has died aged 91.

title.children: One of Australia's most celebrated indigenous leaders has died aged 91

image.altText: A police officer at the scene of the stabbing at Redbank Plains with police tape and flowers set down beside a pole.

props.synopsis: Queensland police will investigate "around the clock" until they arrest the man responsible for the "abhorrent" killing of a grandmother at a shopping centre west of Brisbane.

title.children: Search continues after woman dies following stabbing in front of grandchild

image.altText: A composite image of Leonard O'Meara and a drone shot of his house in Derby, WA.

props.synopsis: There are calls for an ASIC investigation after an Indigenous pensioner was charged an annual insurance premium of almost $10,000 by QBE for an asbestos-clad home in a remote town in Western Australia.

title.children: Calls for investigation after pensioner charged $54k for home insurance on 'asbestos cottage'

image.altText: A young woman in a three-piece suit and handcuffs is escorted by a man and a woman

props.synopsis: Fifty years ago, a teenaged heiress with a famous last name was kidnapped from her California apartment by armed terrorists. What followed was one of the most confounding crimes in American history.

title.children: This kidnapped heiress-turned-revolutionary was despised in America. Then a Hollywood star spoke out

image.altText: A designed image showing Malcolm Turnbull gesturing with his finger and Barnaby Joyce  looking downcast.

props.synopsis: The former merchant banker and bush accountant enjoyed an unlikely but successful political partnership. That all changed when Malcolm Turnbull strode into his courtyard and denounced Barnaby Joyce in front of the nation over his affair with a staffer, Vikki Campion.

title.children: 'I just saw him as an idiot': Barnaby Joyce on the moment Malcolm Turnbull denounced his affair

image.altText: Farmer stands in a wide field under a cloudy sky.

props.synopsis: The issues that led to the royal commission five years ago have faded, even if they haven't all been fixed. As new issues like scams and the impact of artificial intelligence capture attention, advocates want banks to keep a focus on doing the right thing by their customers.

title.children: Charging dead people, stealing billions — the five years that cleaned up banking

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: So, you think you're good at quizzes but don't have the guts to front up to my actual TV show? Well, try this then.

title.children: Hard Quiz: You better believe I'm here to judge you. Let's play HARD!

image.altText: A man holds a petrol bowser while filling up his car.

props.synopsis: The federal government will introduce laws that will set fuel efficiency standards on new cars being sold in Australia.

title.children: New cars to be subject to new efficiency standards

image.altText: Inside of a shopping mall at Christmas time. Unsplash.

props.synopsis: A raft of official economic data suggests Australia's economy suddenly hit a wall in December. Is the data wrong, or did the Reserve Bank raise rates one time too many in November?

title.children: 'Did the Australian economy just snap'? It may be 'unlikely' but it's looking more and more possible

image.altText: APN Houthi Yemen weapons car

props.synopsis: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin says his country and its allies will not hesitate to defend the flow of free commerce through the Red Sea, where the Houthis have been targeting vessels.

title.children: US strikes Houthi weapons sites in Yemen with Australian support

image.altText: Two women pose while making videos on TikTok highlighting their legs

props.synopsis: A social media trend encouraging women and girls to compare the look of their legs in leggings has been prompted warnings from experts and led to the associated hashtag being banned on TikTok.

title.children: What is the 'legging legs' trend, and why has the hashtag been blocked by TikTok?

image.altText: A woman in a gold dress on a motorbike with a gun

props.synopsis: A successful viral hoax generated a lot of buzz for star-studded campy action comedy Argylle. Does it live up to the hype?

title.children: If nothing else, Argylle is a testament to the magic of movie marketing

image.altText: Lewis Hamilton, in his race suit, no helmet, wearing sunglasses, looking upward with a smile in the paddock

props.synopsis: Seven-time Formula 1 world champion Lewis Hamilton has made his first comments following the announcement he will join Ferrari at the start of the 2025 season.

title.children: Hamilton says Ferrari move is a 'childhood dream' after bombshell defection announced

image.altText: Harry Souttar consoles Lewis Miller after the Socceroos' Asian Cup loss to South Korea.

props.synopsis: Socceroos defender Harry Souttar says criticism and abuse of Australia's players during the team's failed Asian Cup tilt went too far.

title.children: 'It doesn't sit right': Souttar calls out personal abuse of Socceroos after Asian Cup exit

image.altText: A woman with long blond hair and a beige blazer sits in a chair at a tram stop

props.synopsis: Child sexual abuse survivor Laura Rowe speaks out following the conviction of her brother. She says the justice system needs to be overhauled to make it easier for others to navigate.

title.children: Laura's brother abused her. She says bringing him to justice has been harder than it should be

image.altText: A pop art illustration of a woman wearing sunglasses, with thumbs up emojis in the glass.

props.synopsis: Human preoccupation with beauty has a long history, but these experts say something new is at play.

title.children: Beautiful people are better liked, richer and more successful. Two philosophers explain why

image.altText: Harry Dannock in karate uniform.

props.synopsis: Harry was 10 when clenching his fists during karate classes became difficult. But the real turning point came when he asked his mum and dad to stop hugging him because it hurt too much.

title.children: Tasmanian children waiting months be diagnosed with juvenile arthritis due to lack of specialists

image.altText: Charlie Smith smiling in his sunflower crop.

props.synopsis: Charlie Smith spent his school holidays growing sunflowers with his dad on their Manjimup farm in WA's South West and has big aspirations for his little business.

title.children: 'I want to grow over one trillion sunflowers': Young farmer aims high with new roadside venture

image.altText: Joko Widido left shakes hands with a crowd of supporters next to his son who is also greeting people.

props.synopsis: Less than a fortnight out from Indonesia's election, President Joko Widodo's son is proving to be the decisive factor driving some of the country's almost 200 million voters towards his joint ticket. Could he secure the Widodo political dynasty?

title.children: With the possible rise of a nepo baby, Widodo went from anti-dynasty candidate to kingmaker

image.altText: A silhouette stature of a man holding a spear in front of a sunset.

props.synopsis: John Pat's death at just 16 inside an outback police lock-up sparked national outrage and a royal commission. Forty years later, what is his legacy in his hometown?

title.children: The shocking death of a 16-year-old in police custody 40 years ago continues to reverberate in this outback town

image.altText: A graphic showing a man coughing, a rapid antigen COVID test and three spike proteins

props.synopsis: Behind the scenes governments have been steadily dismantling many other elements of a surveillance system that we were so reliant on in the emergency period of the COVID-19 pandemic, writes Casey Briggs.

title.children: If you've tried to look up COVID cases recently, you'll have noticed something has changed

image.altText: A woman holds up plastic sporting armour

props.synopsis: A new world-first protective armour, designed just for women in sport, hopes to prolong careers and minimise injuries.

title.children: 'Game changer' sports gear puts women's protection on global agenda

image.altText: an aerial of a flooded proeprty

props.synopsis: The system is finishing up its outback tour and heading towards New South Wales this week as another possible cyclone intensifies in the Coral Sea east of Queensland.

title.children: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Kirrily isolates outback residents for weeks as Coral Sea low gains strength

image.altText: Joe Biden stands in front of presidential podium

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden has won South Carolina's Democratic primary, notching an overwhelming 2024 victory in the state that vaulted him to the White House four years ago.

title.children: US President Joe Biden wins South Carolina’s Democratic primary

image.altText: NT Police car flashing lights

props.synopsis: Four people were killed in a single vehicle crash on the remote Roper Highway, with a pedestrian also struck and killed in a separate incident in Darwin's rural area.

title.children: Five people killed in two separate crashes on NT roads in one night

image.altText: A hand holds almonds growing on a tree.

props.synopsis: Experts warning a water shortage is inevitable as almonds become the biggest crop by area planted on Australia's longest river.

title.children: Almonds are now Australia's most valuable horticultural export, but one shelled nut takes 8 litres of water to grow

image.altText: Four jars of honey sitting on a bench

props.synopsis: Beekeepers say cheap foreign honey is pushing prices down to unsustainable levels but importers say they are providing options to value-conscious shoppers.

title.children: Bulk honey imports started during the millennium drought. Now at near-record levels beekeepers aren't happy

image.altText: A jet ski in the water near a rocky coastline, searching the water.

props.synopsis: An extensive search is underway after a man was swept from rocks while fishing in the Port Stephens area. It comes after a man was found dead on rocks in a separate incident on the NSW North Coast.

title.children: Fisherman missing while another found dead on rocks as rough seas pound NSW coastline

image.altText: Two women stand in a parliamentary lobby wearing semi-formal attire, smiling.

props.synopsis: Jude Hudson was whisked away to give birth in a home for unwed mothers in her mid-teens, then her baby girl was taken from her. She may now be entitled to compensation for Victorian mothers forced to put their children up for adoption.

title.children: Mother separated from daughter for 18 years among first to apply for Australian-first redress scheme

image.altText: A man pours a bucket of water on a burning building.

props.synopsis: At least 46 people have been killed by wildfires in Chile with the death toll expected to rise.

title.children: Raging forest fires kill at least 46 in Chile; toll expected to rise

image.altText: Kate Selway working in glacial wind

props.synopsis: Kate Selway has spent the past two months battling subzero temperatures, perpetual sunlight, and getting stuck on the ice to help unlock the secrets of Antarctica’s melting glaciers.

title.children: Kate spent summer in Antarctica. This is what it’s like to live in one of the most remote places on Earth
